author: By Jon Meacham
title: Jackie Robinson’s Inner Struggle
description: Books by an American icon tell the story of his battle against bigotry from the inside.
content: It was Tuesday, Sept. 30, 1947 — Game 1 of the World Series between the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers — and Jack Roosevelt “Jackie” Robinson was making history. The Dodger first baseman was standing in a packed Yankee Stadium about to hear the national anthem. From a distance, the tableau can seem an inspiring inflection point: the first Black major leaguer in the 20th century playing in the first televised World Series. “There I was,” Robinson recalled in his 1972 memoir “I Never Had It Made: An Autobiography,” “the Black grandson of a slave, the son of a Black sharecropper, part of a historic occasion, a symbolic hero to my people.” So far, so good: The safe narrative of Robinson-as-stoic-hero is intact. “The band struck up the national anthem,” he wrote. “It should have been a glorious moment for me as the stirring words … poured from the stands.” Yet if we see the scene through Robinson’s eyes — and hear the anthem through his ears — we encounter an altogether different story. Writing a quarter of a century after the 1947 World Series, Robinson observed, “I cannot stand and sing the anthem. I cannot salute the flag; I know that I am a Black man in a white world. In 1972, in 1947, at my birth in 1919, I know that I never had it made.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Yankee Stadium Area Is Hurting, and Baseball’s Return Won’t Help
description: Merchants and vendors around the ballpark are struggling to survive in a summer devoid of the usual crowds.
content: By this point in a normal summer, the New York Yankees would have drawn more than 1.8 million fans to their palatial stadium in the South Bronx. On game days, the bars and souvenir shops around the ballpark would be overflowing with customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Timely Case on Police Violence at the Supreme Court
description: The justices will hear arguments in October over whether excessive force claims against the police are barred when the people they shoot get away.
content: Early on a summer morning in Albuquerque in 2014, two state police officers in dark tactical gear arrived at a housing complex to serve an arrest warrant. In the parking lot, they came upon Roxanne Torres, sitting in her car with the engine running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: A Navy Veteran Had a Question for the Feds in Portland. They Beat Him in Response.
description: The veteran said he wanted to ask the officers whether they felt their actions violated the Constitution. Video shows them tear-gassing him and smashing his hand with baton blows.
content: Christopher J. David had largely ignored the protests in downtown Portland, Ore., but when he saw videos of unidentified federal agents grabbing protesters off the street and throwing them into rented minivans, he felt compelled to act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: An Ex-Times Reporter. An Ohio Wedding Provider. Covid Contrarians Go Viral.
description: Anger at lockdowns and mask mandates provides fertile ground for arguments about the best way to fight the virus.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — If you’ve been following Gov. Mike DeWine’s coronavirus news conferences the way that New Yorkers follow Andrew Cuomo’s, you know Jack Windsor: He’s the reporter asking about creeping Marxism among contact tracers and suggesting that Ohio is double counting virus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Stovall
title: A Retelling of American History — in Neon
description: Maya Stovall, known for her dance performances in public spaces, shares a new artwork.
content: In this new series, The Artists, an installment of which will publish every day this week and regularly thereafter, T will highlight a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist, putting the work into context. First up is a piece by Maya Stovall, who is best known for her dance performances in public spaces, as documented in her “Liquor Store Theater” video series, which will screen this summer as part of the citywide digital-art exhibition “Art Mile Detroit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: ‘If It’s Here, It’s Here’: America’s Retirees Confront the Virus in Florida
description: As cases spike across Florida, the virus appears to have caught up with the residents of the Villages.
content: THE VILLAGES, Fla. — For months, many of the residents at one of America’s biggest retirement communities went about their lives as if the coronavirus barely existed. They played bridge. They held dances. They went to house parties in souped-up golf carts that looked like miniature Jaguars and Rolls-Royces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Emitt Rhodes, 70, Dies; Singer-Songwriter Vanished After a Splash
description: He resurfaced a decade ago, after having built a fan base that compared him to Paul McCartney.
content: Emitt Rhodes, a singer and songwriter who earned a cult status among fans of Beatles-like power-pop for a handful of albums he released in the early 1970s, then gave up recording for decades, has died at 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Global Warming Is Driving Polar Bears Toward Extinction, Researchers Say
description: By century’s end, polar bears worldwide could become nearly extinct as a result of shrinking sea ice in the Arctic if climate change continues unabated, scientists said.
content: Polar bears could become nearly extinct by the end of the century as a result of shrinking sea ice in the Arctic if global warming continues unabated, scientists said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Tiffany May
title: Once a Model City, Hong Kong Grapples With a New Coronavirus Wave
description: Doctors are seeing more cases a day than they had in previous outbreaks, and a number of infections with unknown origin have made the outbreak harder to contain.
content: Hong Kong once seemed like a model for how to control the coronavirus. Schools were open. Restaurants and malls buzzed with crowds. Buses and trains operated as usual, with residents dutifully wearing face masks on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Ailey II Drops Director, Citing ‘Inappropriate’ Communications
description: Troy Powell, who has led the dance company as artistic director since 2012, was let go after an inquiry by an outside investigator hired by the organization.
content: Troy Powell was dropped as the artistic director of Ailey II, the junior troupe of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, after an outside investigation concluded that he had engaged in “inappropriate communications” with adult students in the company’s training program, a spokesman for the company said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Live Webinar: Give Students a Voice by Incorporating Contests in Your Curriculum
description: Join us on July 23 to learn how to use one or more of our 10 student contests as unit projects or enrichment opportunities this school year.
content: For 11 years now, The Learning Network has been running contests that offer students a chance to share their ideas and opinions with the world. Through photography and editorials or personal narratives and podcasts, our contests give students a voice and the opportunity to write for an authentic audience. Each year tens of thousands of students participate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bordoff
title: Will Clean Energy Projects Face Troubles That Have Bedeviled Pipelines?
description: If the permit process is not improved, solar and wind energy efforts may face protracted delays or shutdowns.
content: This month, environmentalists celebrated setbacks to three major oil and gas pipelines, nearly a decade after the protests against the Keystone XL pipeline began. Yet what goes around can come around. Legal strategies that have derailed pipelines can also be turned against clean energy projects urgently needed to combat climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Federal Crackdown on Portland Protesters
description: Readers object to the use of federal officers, saying the protests were largely peaceful and any problems should have been handled by local law enforcement.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Monica Davey
title: Trump Threatens to Send Federal Law Enforcement Forces to More Cities
description: As federal agents patrol Portland and head to Chicago, Democrats call the president’s plan “an American crisis,” barely 100 days before the election.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to deploy federal law enforcement to Chicago and threatened on Monday to send agents to other major cities — all controlled by Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Republicans Begin New Relief Talks as Hopes Fade for Rapid Recovery
description: Hong Kong’s experience provides a cautionary tale as it grapples with a new virus wave. Teachers’ unions sued Florida’s governor over an order requiring schools to reopen despite surging cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What You Don’t Know Can’t Hurt Trump
description: “Slow the testing down,” he said, and it’s happening.
content: We’re now at the stage of the Covid-19 pandemic where Donald Trump and his allies are trying to suppress information about the coronavirus’s spread — because, of course, they are. True to form, however, they’re far behind the curve. From a political point of view (which is all they care about), their disinformation efforts are too little, too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City’s Phase 4, Explained
description: It's a landmark in the reopening process, but with bans remaining on indoor dining, cinemas and museums, life is hardly back to normal.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Georgia Democrats Choose Nikema Williams to Fill John Lewis’s Seat in Congress
description: Ms. Williams, a state senator, is considered the overwhelming favorite in the general election this fall.
content: ATLANTA — Nikema Williams, a state senator from Atlanta, emerged from a conclave of Georgia Democratic officials on Monday as the appointed successor to Representative John Lewis, taking his place on the November ballot and very likely inheriting the seat he occupied in Congress for 17 terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Marchese
title: ‘It’s a Risk for Everybody’: Why a Jazz Pianist Chose to Perform
description: More than four months after his last public performance, the Grammy-winning artist Bill Charlap played at a storied Pennsylvania club, a glimpse into what may be the new normal for musicians.
content: On Saturday, four months and 10 days since his last public performance, the Grammy-winning jazz pianist Bill Charlap came out to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Trump Says He ‘Aced’ a Cognitive Test. What Does That Really Mean?
description: Experts say one popular test that the president might have taken is by no means definitive, or even diagnostic.
content: In recent interviews, President Trump has been boasting about a cognitive test that he took recently and “aced.” It’s not the first time — he made similar remarks in January 2018. But he once again has not said what test he took, or what his score was, making it difficult to know what to make of his claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Sandra E. Garcia
title: A Rush to Use Black Art Leaves the Artists Feeling Used
description: Black creative professionals say they have been used to lend legitimacy to diversity campaigns while being underpaid and pigeonholed.
content: The streets of New York were crowded with protesters when Shantell Martin received an email from an ad agency last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Jim Tankersley and Nicholas Fandos
title: Republicans, Still at Odds Over Aid Package, Eye $1 Trillion Opening Offer
description: Congressional Republicans and the White House are still debating a number of central issues as lawmakers look to unveil their proposal.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans toiled on Monday to resolve their differences with President Trump over the next coronavirus relief package, working to smooth out internal divisions ahead of what promises to be an intense battle with Democrats over providing federal aid to confront a virus that continues to surge and batter the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: There are promising developments in potential vaccines and treatments.
content: More than four months into the pandemic, there are promising developments in the two areas that the world is betting on to halt the spread of the coronavirus: vaccines and treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Risch
title: With a U.N. Veto, Russia and China Add to Syria’s Misery
description: Moscow and Beijing are callously restricting humanitarian aid to Syria’s suffering civilians as part of their campaign to prop up Bashar al-Assad.
content: Earlier this month in the United Nations Security Council, the world saw a preview of what Russian and Chinese global “leadership” looks like: a world order where the most vulnerable suffer for the political gains of those at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Tim Gruber
title: Baseball in Middle America: Fans Are In, Autographs Are Out
description: Major League Baseball will hold its delayed opening day this week, with no fans. In four American cities, though, professional baseball has already returned, pressing ahead in a season like no other.
content: FARGO, N.D. — Forget about everything else for a moment and take a look at this:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Building Accessibility Into America, Literally
description: Thirty years on, the Americans With Disabilities Act has reshaped the way designers and the public have come to think about equity, civil rights and American architecture. But it’s only a start.
content: This article is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for people with disabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: 3 Friends ‘Massacred’ During Florida Fishing Trip, Police Say
description: One of the victims called his father, asking for help, officials said.
content: On a dirt road, near cow pastures, orange groves and lakes, a Florida sheriff said he encountered one of the worst crime scenes in his career last week: Three close friends appeared to have been beaten and shot to death during a nighttime catfishing trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Producer Takes Academy to Task in Lawsuit
description: The Oscars’ social media strategy — and by extension their relevance to younger viewers — underlies the action brought by the producer Michael Shamberg.
content: LOS ANGELES — Tension within the stately Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences spilled into public on Monday when a prominent producer sued the organization over a procedural matter and in the process attacked officials over the troubled state of the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: New Treatment for Covid-19 Shows Promise, but Scientists Urge Caution
description: A small study of an inhaled form of a commonly available drug, interferon beta, suggests it could reduce the odds of patients becoming severely ill.
content: LONDON — A British drug company said Monday that an inhaled form of a commonly used medicine could slash the odds of Covid-19 patients becoming severely ill, a sliver of good news in the race to find treatments that was met by scientists with equal measures of caution and cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: At Least 60 Migrants Killed in Turkish Boat Disaster
description: Rescuers continue to pull the bodies of victims from Lake Van, in eastern Turkey, more than three weeks after the fishing boat carrying them sank.
content: ISTANBUL — Turkish rescue teams have retrieved the bodies of 60 migrants after their boat sank in a lake in the east of the country, Turkish media reported on Monday, in one of the worst disasters involving migrants in Turkey in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Wharton and Koren Shadmi
title: Marcella Hazan’s Tomato Sauce Trilogy
description: Subtle changes in method yield completely different results in these three simple and delicious tomato sauces from the cookbook author, who would have been 96 this year.
content: Follow NYT Food on Twitter and NYT Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane
title: Defying Trump, Lawmakers Move to Strip Military Bases of Confederate Names
description: The push by both Republicans and Democrats in Congress sets up an election-year veto fight with the president, and shows how he has isolated himself even from members of his own party on the issue.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Don Bacon, a Republican, had a blunt message for President Trump when a White House aide called him personally early this month and asked that he abandon legislation to strip the names of Confederate leaders from military bases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘I Have to Go in and Decolonize’: Europe’s Black Theater Makers Discuss the Scene
description: Kwame Kwei-Armah, Julia Wissert and Eva Doumbia met online this week to talk about challenging the establishment, Black Lives Matter and the issue of white universality.
content: LONDON — This summer, a coalition of American theater artists issued a statement, “We See You, White American Theater,” calling for an overhaul of the country’s theater landscape. There should be term limits on theater industry leaders to improve representation, it said, and at least half of casts and creative teams should be people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Lloyd
title: What Is It That Keeps Most Little Kids From Getting Covid-19?
description: Young children have consistently been slow to catch and spread Covid-19. Experts have a few hunches why.
content: On the way home from a jog one afternoon in early July, Dr. Silvia Chiang noticed her husband and 2½-year-old daughter playing outdoors with a handful of neighborhood kids and their moms in face masks. As someone who specializes in pediatric infectious diseases and has helped care for dozens of children with Covid-19, Chiang said she felt uneasy at one point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Facing a Season of Uncertainty, Max Scherzer Is Still Tinkering
description: “I don’t come to the park for all the other hoopla; I come to the park because I want to win another World Series with my teammates,” Scherzer said days before opening the 2020 season.
content: The last competitive game Max Scherzer pitched was the biggest of his life. And he was not about to let the designated hitter rule disrupt his routine before Game 7 of the World Series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Big Polling Leads Tend to Erode. Is Biden’s Edge Different?
description: As his advantage endures well into its second month, it becomes harder to assume that it’s just another fleeting shift.
content: Joe Biden’s commanding advantage in the race for the White House shows no sign of abating. He led by 15 percentage points in an ABC News/Washington Post survey of registered voters on Sunday, and he has held a nearly double-digit lead in an average of polls for more than a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Aimee Ortiz
title: Felony Charges Filed Against St. Louis Couple Who Pointed Guns at Protesters
description: “It is illegal to wave weapons in a threatening manner,” a prosecutor in the city said.
content: Felony charges have been filed against a St. Louis couple who pointed guns at protesters marching past their home last month in an episode that was captured on video and drew the attention of a divided nation, including President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Views on Covid Tests and Vaccines
description: Readers criticize the president’s desire to eliminate funds for testing and point to his earlier vaccine skepticism. Also: New York City’s air quality; life in a van.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Chevron Deal for Oil and Gas Fields May Set Off New Wave of Mergers
description: With a $5 billion play for Noble Energy, the oil giant is set to acquire properties around the world for a relative bargain. Other companies might make similar moves.
content: HOUSTON — In the first big deal since oil prices crashed four months ago, Chevron agreed on Monday to buy Noble Energy for roughly $5 billion in what many experts consider the beginning of a sweeping consolidation in the U.S. oil industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sue Li
title: This Chicken Salad Comes With a Kick
description: A tahini-wasabi dressing finishes this any occasion recipe inspired, in part, by a Taiwanese-Chinese dish.
content: The next time you get delivery or takeout, don’t throw away those condiments. Use them in your next dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Svetkey
title: Oliver Stone’s Reel History
description: In “Chasing the Light,” the Oscar-winning director and screenwriter has finally found a historical figure he can portray with all the bias he desires: himself.
content: CHASING THE LIGHTWriting, Directing, and Surviving “Platoon,” “Midnight Express,” “Scarface,” “Salvador,” and the Movie GameBy Oliver Stone
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: ‘Less Optimistic’ and ‘More Cautious’: Top C.E.O.s Fret as Virus Cases Rise
description: Many of the nation’s business leaders are steeling themselves for a period of prolonged economic disruption and the prospect of a slow, halting recovery.
content: With coronavirus cases around the country on the rise and states rolling back their reopening plans, many of the nation's top business leaders are steeling themselves for a period of prolonged economic disruption and the prospect of a slow, halting recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 20, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 20, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 20, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Jailed Soccer Official Contracts Coronavirus in Florida Prison
description: Juan Ángel Napout, a former FIFA vice president convicted in a corruption case, said he had tested positive at a federal facility that is struggling to contain an outbreak.
content: Juan Ángel Napout, a former vice president of soccer’s governing body FIFA serving a nine-year sentence for corruption, has tested positive for the coronavirus inside a Miami federal prison. The positive result came days after a federal judge denied his appeal for compassionate release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Suspends Extradition Treaty With Hong Kong Over Security Law
description: Several foreign governments have criticized the new law, which gives China broad powers to crack down on political crimes in the territory.
content: LONDON — In an escalation of tensions with China, Britain on Monday suspended an extradition treaty with Hong Kong to protest a new security law that gives China sweeping powers and is seen by critics as imperiling basic freedoms in the former British colony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Black Children Are More Likely to Die After Surgery Than White Peers, Study Shows
description: A large study, published in the journal Pediatrics, suggests that disparities exist in surgery outcomes, even among healthy children.
content: Black children are more than three times as likely to die within a month of surgery as white children, according to a study published in the journal Pediatrics on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: A Stadium at Iowa State Says His Name: Jack Trice
description: Iowa State is the only major college football team to have named its stadium after a Black man, a player named Jack Trice who died from injuries sustained in a game in 1923 and whose story resonates amid today’s social justice movement.
content: Of the 130 universities that play major college football, only one — Iowa State — has a stadium named after an African-American person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Danny Meyer’s Restaurants Will End Their No-Tipping Policy
description: Union Square Hospitality Group, which helped lead the move away from tips, changes course as its restaurants reopen.
content: One of the country’s best-known restaurateurs, Danny Meyer, announced five years ago that his Union Square Hospitality Group would gradually eliminate tipping. The group’s decision began an industrywide examination of the age-old practice, but adopting it proved complicated, especially in New York State, where laws governing tip distribution are strict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Smorgasburg Returns, With Some Covid-19 Changes
description: Fans of the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, food fair will be able to order takeout from a rotating lineup of 10 vendors.
content: Smorgasburg has reopened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, but for now, the chance to graze from a buffet of food vendors, is off the table. Smorg To Go only allows preordering through its new website for takeout from a weekly rotating list of 10 vendors. There are three new ones in the starting lineup: #Gogi for Korean pork barbecue; Mai Bpen Rai, a Thai papaya salad stand; and the Whole Bowl, a Portland, Ore., transplant serving rice and beans. They join stalwarts like Berg’s Pastrami, Lobsterdamus and Mao’s Bao. The week of July 27 will welcome Groundlings Pizza, Ring Ding Bar and Yakitori Tatsu, among others. There is no outdoor seating. Through its website, Smorg To Go is raising funds for Rethink, which fights food insecurity in many neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: You’ve Heard of Boxed Wine. Enter the Boxed Negroni.
description: St. Agrestis, a Brooklyn spirits company, now sells a 1.75-liter version of its bottled cocktail, enough for about 20 quarantine drinks.
content: Cocktails on tap? From your fridge? St. Agrestis, the Brooklyn spirits company specializing in Italian-style aperitivos and digestivos, has introduced Negronis in a box, 1.75 liters (almost two quarts) of premixed cocktail. Like St. Agrestis’s bottled Negroni, the drink consists of the company’s Inferno Bitter spirit, their own vermouth and Greenhook Ginsmiths Gin for a properly complex and forceful drink (24 percent alcohol). A splash of water or soda won’t hurt; it’s not included so you can add your own. Keep the box in the refrigerator, ready to pour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Aimee Ortiz and Kevin Armstrong
title: Husband and Son of a Federal Judge Are Shot in New Jersey
description: Judge Esther Salas was home but not wounded in the shooting at her residence in North Brunswick, according to an official.
content: A gunman shot the son of a federal judge at her home in New Jersey on Sunday, according to an official with knowledge of the situation. The Associated Press reported that he had died and that the judge’s husband also had been shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Hotels Nix Mints and Breakfast Buffets. Hand Sanitizer, Anyone?
description: “Shellshocked” by the pandemic and the drop-off in business, hotels are rethinking amenities and trying to allay travelers’ concerns.
content: Those hotel amenities you took for granted, like throw pillows, turndown service and free coffee in the lobby? They’re gone. Housekeeping is by request or eliminated during your stay. And don’t even think of finding a self-serve breakfast buffet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: India Outbreak, Hong Kong, Bali Economy: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amisha Padnani and Dan Sanchez
title: Exploring What Disability Means Today, and Could Mean Tomorrow
description: Thirty years after the passage of the A.D.A., a Times project featuring more than two dozen articles looks at the many facets of the law’s impact and the work that still lies ahead.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong, William K. Rashbaum and Mihir Zaveri
title: ‘Anti-Feminist’ Lawyer Is Suspect in Killing of Son of Federal Judge in N.J.
description: Roy Den Hollander had openly seethed against the judge, Esther Salas. After the shooting at her home, he was found dead in an apparent suicide.
content: Roy Den Hollander was a self-described “anti-feminist” lawyer who flooded the courts with seemingly frivolous lawsuits that sought to eliminate women’s studies programs and prohibit nightclubs from holding “ladies’ nights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: Leaps of Faith
description: Emily Dodson puts her fate in Sister Alice’s hands — and in Perry’s. But Alice and Perry are taking major gambles, too.
content: It begins with the death of a lawyer and ends with the anointing of a new one. In between, this episode of “Perry Mason” covers a good deal of ground with nearly all of its characters, from the fed-up Black cop, Paul Drake, to the true-believer evangelist, Sister Alice, to the dogged legal secretary, Della Street, to the title character. It’s the hour when “Perry Mason” stops being an origin story and starts becoming the first proper Perry Mason case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roff Smith
title: A Glimpse Inside the Workshops of the World’s Finest Panama Hat Makers
description: Creamy as silk and costlier than gold, a Montecristi superfino Panama hat is as much a work of art as it is of fashion.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Roff Smith shares a collection of photographs from the workshops of hat artisans in Ecuador.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Opera Foundation Removes Trustee for Racially Charged Comments
description: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which gives prestigious awards to young singers, removed Richard Tucker’s son from its board.
content: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which grants prestigious awards to young singers, removed David N. Tucker from its board of directors on Monday evening. Mr. Tucker, a son of the distinguished tenor for whom the foundation is named, was removed after an uproar over racially charged comments that he made on a Black singer’s Facebook page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Cinnamon Bun From Aquavit
description: These tempting sticky buns from the chef Emma Bengtsson are now available for takeout in Midtown Manhattan.
content: Spices like cinnamon and cardamom bring alluring fragrance to all sorts of Scandinavian foods, most notably baked goods like a classic swirled bun to pair with your morning coffee. The soft, slightly chewy and well-burnished breakfast pastries, showered with pearl sugar, from the chef Emma Bengtsson at Aquavit are heavenly scented with cardamom, too. And now they’re available retail for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Juice WRLD’s ‘Legends Never Die’ Earns the Year’s Biggest Debut
description: The album is the second posthumous release in a row to top the chart this year, after Pop Smoke’s last week.
content: Juice WRLD, the rapper and singer from Chicago who died in December at age 21, has landed the biggest opening week of the year so far with a posthumous release, “Legends Never Die.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Not Rockin’ the Suburbs
description: The suburbs are the political bellwether of our time. And right now, President Trump is losing them. Badly.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: C.E.O.s Say ‘It’s a Grind’
description: Corporate leaders are increasingly gloomy about the economic recovery, citing the fight over masks and the prospect of renewed lockdowns.
content: Hong Kong, considered an exemplar of coronavirus containment, is seeing a surge in infections — a warning for the rest of the world. And a new study in South Korea suggests that children older than 10 can spread the virus as readily as adults, which could complicate school reopenings. More on that below. (Want this delievered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Jon Rahm’s Two New Attributes: Composure and a Top Ranking
description: With his win at the Memorial Tournament on Sunday, the previously petulant Rahm takes over the No. 1 world ranking.
content: DUBLIN, Ohio — Sometimes a reputation is hard to shake. Just ask Jon Rahm, who for years was best known as a good golfer with a bad temper. But on Sunday evening, Rahm became renowned for being something else: the world’s new No. 1 ranked golfer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Businesses Are Supposed to Cut Debt in a Downturn. Why Not Now?
description: The Federal Reserve’s efforts to stabilize markets have touched off an even bigger borrowing binge than corporate America was already on.
content: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, American corporations have taken advantage of historically low interest rates to gorge themselves on debt. Then came the pandemic and the sharpest economic downturn in history, which resulted in an odd solution for the companies that did all that borrowing: more debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: From Good Wine, a Direct Path to the Wonders of Nature
description: For this city dweller, wine provided the opening to a greater understanding of food and agriculture, and their precarious balance.
content: Last year a friend asked me a question I had never considered before: Over the many years I had been writing about wine, what was the greatest thing this job had given me?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Why a Medical Interpreter Felt ‘Disposable’ Amid Covid-19
description: For Marta Rodriguez helping very sick patients understand their prognosis has become routine — but it hasn’t become any easier.
content: — Marta Rodriguez, a medical interpreter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: ‘A Place Where Everybody Can Shop’ Is Closing Its Doors
description: The famed department store Tati is shutting. And a lot of people are very sad.
content: PARIS — Tati is a ghost of what it once was, and soon it won’t even be that. Shelves that were crammed with dish-scrubbers and brassieres for $1.50 and plaster figurines of smiling bunnies are now bare. Exits are still numbered — how else to find your way out through the crowds — but the aisles are empty. There are no crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Bluestone
title: ‘Total Bellas’ Refuse to Be Knocked Out by Quarantine
description: The twin reality stars and retired WWE champions Nikki and Brie Bella are both pregnant and making TV.
content: When Nikki and Brie Bella, twin sisters who are also reality stars and recently retired WWE champions, found out they were both pregnant last November, they were most excited about the pizookies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Roberts
title: H.I.V. Survivors Confront Painful Memories and New Risks in Pandemic
description: Monday: Around Palm Springs, survivors of the AIDS crisis found community, but old fears are returning. Also: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced school reopening rules.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Link Between Parkinson’s Disease and Toxic Chemicals
description: A new book calls the increasing prominence of Parkinson’s “a man-made pandemic.”
content: Michael Richard Clifford, a 66-year-old retired astronaut living in Cary, N.C., learned before his third spaceflight that he had Parkinson’s disease. He was only 44 and in excellent health at the time, and had no family history of this disabling neurological disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller
title: In a Time of Crisis, Is Art Essential?
description: T’s 2020 summer art issue coincides with a breakdown of the status quo, both in the art world and the real one. Not for nothing, we’ve titled it “True Believers.”
content: For the last two summers, T has published an online art issue in which we celebrate artistic freedom in the face of overwhelming odds. Traditionally, these odds have revolved around an international supply chain largely fueled by greed: The small but powerful ecosystem that we refer to as “the art world” has always exploited artists to protect its profit margins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Allyson Waller
title: TV Reporter Dies After Accident Involving Revel Scooter
description: Nina Kapur was a passenger on a scooter rented from Revel, whose Vespa-style rental vehicles have become popular in New York City. It was believed to be the company’s first fatality.
content: A local television journalist died over the weekend, the police said, after she fell from a scooter that had been rented from Revel, a moped-sharing company whose Vespa-style vehicles have become a familiar sight on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Vegan Ice Creams With Cheffy Flavors
description: Eclipse Foods has collaborated with chefs around the country on plant-based ice cream flavors, with some proceeds going to charitable causes.
content: A scoop of Eclipse blackberry-tarragon ice cream devised by the chef Greg Baxtrom comes topped with support for his restaurant Olmsted’s food bank, active in Brooklyn. Toasted almond thyme ice cream by Nicole Krasinski, an owner and the pastry chef at State Bird Provisions in San Francisco, benefits Black Earth Farms, a Black and Indigenous farming collective in the East Bay of San Francisco. These are just two of the options from Eclipse, a company that is collaborating on flavors with chefs, who designate charities that will receive the proceeds. Though there’s chocolate and vanilla, most of the flavors in the “chef series” are unusual. In fact calling any of these ice creams, despite their rich mouth feel and texture, is something of a misnomer since they’re entirely plant-based, using ingredients like cassava and corn to deliver the creaminess. The company, which began selling its confections late last year, has now made them available nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Fix yourself a sandwich, whether it’s Melissa Clark’s garlicky interpretation, full of juicy tomatoes, or one of your own making.
content: Good morning. My pal Ricky turned me on to a breakfast sandwich of the sort I used to order in delis or bodegas or bagel shops, back when I frequented them daily: toasted sesame bagel with butter and Swiss cheese. That’s a great sandwich: simple, salty, vaguely sweet, with a tang from the cheese. If you ask for it with ham, stipulate one slice only. Any more than that, and it’s a lunch sandwich, better consumed with mayonnaise and mustard, sliced pickles, a side of chips.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Top Democrats Send Letter on Possible Foreign Meddling in November Election
description: Georgia Democrats named Nikema Williams as successor to John Lewis. President Trump threatened to send federal troops to cities run “by radical left” to temper unrest. And the Jacksonville sheriff said the city was not ready to provide security for the Republican convention.
content: This briefing has now ended. Follow all of our coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: Stay Safe, Justice Ginsburg
description: This summer has been hard enough.
content: HOUSTON — The only word to describe life here right now is this: hell.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Life and Legacy of John Lewis
description: A look at the extraordinary life of the civil rights icon.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Jesse McKinley
title: Sheldon Silver, Former N.Y. Assembly Speaker, Will Finally Go to Prison
description: Mr. Silver receives a sentence of 78 months after two trials. He had asked for home confinement, arguing that he was vulnerable to the coronavirus.
content: Sheldon Silver, the once dominant New York State Assembly speaker who for nearly five years fended off prison after being convicted twice on corruption charges, lost a final bid for freedom on Monday when he was sentenced to 78 months in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Tracy McGrady and Jermaine O’Neal Have Been Talking. They’re Starting a Sports Agency.
description: The former All-Stars, who both entered the N.B.A. straight from high school, hope to share their experiences in the league with potential clients entering the 2021 draft.
content: Tracy McGrady and Jermaine O’Neal were high-profile teenagers who shared the same agent and sneaker brand in January 1998, when a mutual acquaintance suggested that they meet for a meal. They went to an Applebee’s restaurant in Portland, Ore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Ranch Dressing, but Make It Greek
description: Williams Sonoma is selling the seasoning mix for Souvla’s popular “Granch,” a Greek yogurt ranch dressing.
content: Souvla, a chain of casual Greek restaurants in San Francisco, created a Greek yogurt-based version of ranch dressing six years ago, calling it Granch. They even trademarked it. Now the seasoning it depends on is being packaged and sold nationwide by Williams Sonoma. The mixture of buttermilk powder, herbs and spices, along with your lemon juice and salt, is designed to transform plain Greek yogurt into a tangy dressing. You might want to add less salt than they suggest, especially if you’re tossing a Greek salad with olives and feta. The dressing works as a topping for lamb burgers, a marinade for chicken or a garnish for cold cucumber soup. It comes in a little metal mug — a miniaturized version of an old-fashioned Greek wine carafe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.4 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor Revival house in Los Angeles, a contemporary home in Menlo Park and a Craftsman-style bungalow in Carpinteria.
content: This house, in the Hollywood Dell section of the Hollywood Hills, was built in the Tudor Revival style popular in 1920s Los Angeles. The actor David Niven, who once lived here, wrote about it in his memoir, “The Moon’s a Balloon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Stimulus, Biden, Polar Bears: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Google Promises Privacy With Virus App but Can Still Collect Location Data
description: Some government agencies that use the software said they were surprised that Google may pick up the locations of certain app users. Others said they had unsuccessfully pushed Google to make a change.
content: When Google and Apple announced plans in April for free software to help alert people of their possible exposure to the coronavirus, the companies promoted it as “privacy preserving” and said it would not track users’ locations. Encouraged by those guarantees, Germany, Switzerland and other countries used the code to develop national virus alert apps that have been downloaded more than 20 million times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Here’s the business news to watch this week.
description: More than 90 companies listed on the S&P 500 report their latest earnings this week. So far, 73 percent of blue-chip companies that have released second-quarter results beat analyst expectations, according to FactSet. Can they keep it up?
content: More than 90 companies listed on the S&P 500 report their latest earnings this week. So far, 73 percent of blue-chip companies that have released second-quarter results beat analyst expectations, according to FactSet. Can they keep it up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How Porky Pig Works From Home
description: He has the perfect work-from-home job. And even he misses people.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daytrian Wilken
title: The Black Sanitation Workers Who Are Saying, ‘I Am a Man’
description: A determined handful of men in New Orleans carry on the cause Dr. King died defending in Memphis.
content: “All labor has dignity,” the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told striking sanitation workers in Memphis more than 50 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Europe Said It Was Pandemic-Ready. Pride Was Its Downfall.
description: The coronavirus exposed European countries’ misplaced confidence in faulty models, bureaucratic busywork and their own wealth.
content: LONDON — Prof. Chris Whitty, Britain’s chief medical adviser, stood before an auditorium in a London museum two years ago cataloging deadly epidemics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Sean Piccoli
title: N.Y.C. Enters Phase 4, but Restaurants and Bars Are Left Behind
description: As the city reaches what should have been a momentous day, a wild weekend in Astoria shows the risks that bars can pose.
content: For the 25,000 restaurants and bars in New York City, Monday was supposed to be a day of celebration — the turning point when the city would enter Phase 4, the final phase of reopening after the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 11 Chinese Companies Over Human Rights
description: The move, which affects suppliers to major international brands such as Apple, Ralph Lauren and Tommy Hilfiger, could force companies to sever some ties to China.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday barred 11 new Chinese companies from purchasing American technology and products without a special license, saying the firms were complicit in human rights violations in China’s campaign targeting Muslim minorities in the Xinjiang region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Allies of Trump Start to Break Ranks on Virus
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 20, 2020.
content: “The president got bored with it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Trump’s Occupation of American Cities Has Begun
description: Protesters are being snatched from the streets without warrants. Can we call it fascism yet?
content: The month after Donald Trump’s inauguration, the Yale historian Timothy Snyder published the best-selling book “On Tyranny: Twenty Lessons From the Twentieth Century.” It was part of a small flood of titles meant to help Americans find their bearings as the new president laid siege to liberal democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: After Dismissing Coronavirus Surge, Trump Wants to Talk About the Virus Again
description: The president said he would resume the pandemic briefings that he called off in April, a tacit acknowledgment that the public health crisis he had hoped to put behind him was still ravaging much of the country.
content: WASHINGTON — By the time he canceled the show midseason, even President Trump had grown weary of his televised coronavirus briefings. Angry at the reviews, he declared the briefings “not worth the time & effort,” a conclusion shared by his own advisers and allies who had come to see them as hurting more than helping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: As Trump Slumps, Republican Donors Look to Save the Senate
description: Senators and donors worry that with President Trump in trouble and the House probably out of reach, the Senate could be their last chance to hold power in Washington.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Without Music, Tanglewood Is Empty, Eerie and Beautiful
description: The usually tourist-packed Berkshires confronts a season without the music festival that anchors its summers.
content: LENOX, Mass. — André Bernard was three months old when he attended his first concert at Tanglewood: Benny Goodman playing Mozart’s Clarinet Concerto, in 1956. For nearly every one of the next 63 years, he has made a pilgrimage to the lush, sprawling lawn of this summer music mecca here in the Berkshires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thessaly La Force
title: The Japanese-American Sculptor Who, Despite Persecution, Made Her Mark
description: Seven years after her death, Ruth Asawa is finally being recognized as an American master. What can we learn from this overdue reappraisal?
content: IN 2009, THE New York City auction house Christie’s received an unsolicited query: A woman named Addie Lanier had a painting by Josef Albers, the midcentury abstract artist who pioneered modern arts education. Could Christie’s help her sell it? It wasn’t uncommon for a major auction house like Christie’s to get cold calls. News generated by large sales can create curiosity and spark interest; people often approach auction houses in the hope of confirming that they have been sitting on priceless works of art. Jonathan Laib — then a senior vice president and senior specialist of postwar and contemporary art at Christie’s — was excited to hear of an Albers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: American Fashion Nominates the Designers of the Year. They Really Make You Think.
description: But not in a good way. The Oscars of fashion reflect exactly what the industry needs to change.
content: When the coronavirus prompted the Council of Fashion Designers of America to postpone the 2020 CFDA Fashion Awards, the annual “Oscars of the Fashion World” (industry prom) originally scheduled for June 8, it seemed like another glittering evening of voyeurism and celebration had fallen to the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mustafa Akyol
title: Would the Prophet Muhammad Convert Hagia Sophia?
description: Turkey’s decision to change the former cathedral into a mosque flies against the pluralist instincts of Islam’s founders.
content: The recent decision by the Turkish government to reconvert the majestic Hagia Sophia, which was once the world’s greatest cathedral, from a museum back to a mosque has been bad news for Christians around the world. They include Pope Francis, who said he was “pained” by the move, and the spiritual leader of Eastern Christianity, Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, who said he was “saddened and shaken.” When contrasted with the joy of Turkey’s conservative Muslims, all this may seem like a new episode in an old story: Islam vs. Christianity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shardha Jogee
title: How to Reopen the Economy Without Killing Teachers and Parents
description: All classes should be online, but school buildings could still serve an important purpose for the kids who need them most.
content: The debate about reopening schools seems to pit parents and their employers against teachers. But there is actually a solution that would let grown-ups go back to work, educate kids and keep everyone safe at the same time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: The Pandemic Has Pushed Aside City Planning Rules. But to Whose Benefit?
description: As bike lanes and cafes sprout on streets, marginalized residents wonder when their priorities will get attention.
content: One month into the coronavirus crisis this spring, Oakland, Calif., began to restrict car traffic on some streets — ultimately on 21 miles of them — to create outdoor space for residents who suddenly had nowhere else to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Players Say #WeWantToPlay but Question Training Camp Safety
description: The team owners and the players’ union are deadlocked on several questions governing coronavirus protocols, even as players are scheduled to report this week.
content: The N.F.L. plays football in rainstorms, blizzards and blazing heat. Now, the league wants to play in a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: REI’s response to virus cases angers employees.
description: The outdoor equipment co-op REI is facing a backlash over its handling of coronavirus cases among its employees, with some nervous workers pushing for more transparency as stores reopen.
content: The outdoor equipment co-op REI is facing a backlash over its handling of coronavirus cases among its employees, with some nervous workers pushing for more transparency as stores reopen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What the A.D.A. Means to Me
description: We asked the disability rights activists Judy Heumann, Alice Wong and Haben Girma to reflect on the 30th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act. They said the work of a civil rights activist is never done.
content: This essay is based on an interview of Judy Heumann by Kaitlyn Wells. Ms. Heumann is the co-author of “Being Heumann: An Unrepentant Memoir of a Disability Rights Activist,” with Kristen Joiner, and is featured in the award-winning Netflix documentary “Crip Camp: A Disability Revolution.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering Ennio Morricone, the Film Score Maestro
description: His music was dynamic, bold and idiosyncratic, setting a high bar for composers connecting sound and vision.
content: Ennio Morricone, who died this month at 91, was for decades the most innovative and irreverent composer of film scores working. Best known for his collaborations with Sergio Leone on his spaghetti westerns, Morricone scored approximately 500 films, working with a who’s who of landmark directors: Bernardo Bertolucci, Pier Paolo Pasolini, Terrence Malick, John Carpenter, Quentin Tarantino and many more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: There Are Wasps in the Yard. You’d Better Get to Know Them.
description: They buzz. They hover. Sometimes they sting. But how much do you really know about these insects that can menace our summers?
content: Wasps get a bad rap. And sometimes, they deserve it. Bumblebees don’t swarm your barbecue the moment you pour the lemonade. Butterflies won’t nest by the hundreds in your rafters, then sting you for the crime of walking by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Ip Man 4: The Finale’ and ‘Intervention’
description: The final installment of Wilson Yip’s martial arts series arrives on Netflix. And a new season of “Intervention” begins on A&E.
content: IP MAN 4: THE FINALE (2019) Stream on Netflix.; rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. In this martial arts film Ip Man (Donnie Yen), a real-life Wing Chun master who inspired the series, leaves Hong Kong for San Francisco, where he finds that the popularity of his student, Bruce Lee (Chan Kwok-Kwan Danny), has stirred tensions in the city. Some members of the local Chinese community are opposed to sharing martial arts secrets with non-Chinese students. The movie’s other antagonist is a bigoted Marine (Scott Adkins) who is promoting karate over kung fu. “There is no mystery about who wins the movie’s final bout,” Ben Kenigsberg wrote in his review for The New York Times, “but it is never less than thrilling to watch Yen’s fluttering limbs in action.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: European Union Fund, Bulgaria Protests, Mars Mission: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: For Some Artists, Election Season Means ‘Enough of Trump’
description: More than a dozen artists including Carrie Mae Weems, Ed Ruscha and Shepard Fairey have contributed art to an advocacy campaign aimed at inspiring voters in November.
content: Voters heading to the polls this election season in battleground states like Michigan and Pennsylvania may find themselves facing billboards, projections and even cornfield cutouts designed by the country’s leading artists with a simple refrain: “Enough is enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Celebrate the Catskills in Your Kitchen
description: Regional ingredients are put to delicious use in this bright new farm-to-table cookbook.
content: “The Catskills Farm to Table Cookbook,” a seasonal, brightly photographed survey of the area’s foods and farms, hews closely to what is produced in the region’s five counties in southern New York State. Spring brings nettles, ramps, fiddleheads, garlic scapes, pea pods and even milkweed buds to compelling recipes, like scalloped potatoes in a stinging nettle sauce. Summer adds corn, tomatoes and zucchini; fall offers squash and apples; and in winter there are roots and cabbage. Meats, mainly pork, show up from time to time, and desserts amount mostly to pies, crisps and crumbles. Some ingredients are not listed in order of use, but the recipes work, though the cacio e pepe with greens is better if the greens are chopped first. For the two upside-down apple desserts, a cake and a pie, the author never nods to tarte Tatin, the obvious antecedent, nor does she use the more common name, Dutch babies, for the puff pancake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Death and Testing
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: President Trump gave a confrontational interview to Chris Wallace of Fox News yesterday that included numerous untruths about the coronavirus. Trump claimed that the United States had the lowest death rate in the world; that new cases were surging here mostly because of the large number of tests; and that his virus response had saved “millions of lives.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil and Ken Belson
title: Jets and Giants Are N.F.L.’s First to Say They’ll Play Without Fans
description: Following New Jersey’s restrictions on public gatherings, the two teams announced they would not admit fans for regular-season games at MetLife Stadium. Rutgers will cap spectators at 500.
content: The Jets and Giants will play their regular-season games without fans at MetLife Stadium this fall, the teams announced in a joint statement Monday, nearly three weeks after Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey issued an executive order limiting social gatherings to 500 people. The teams are the first in the N.F.L. to decide to forego fans, and the revenue they bring, when the season begins in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael B. Eisen and Robert Tibshirani
title: How to Identify Flawed Research Before It Becomes Dangerous
description: Scientists and journalists need to establish a service to review research that’s publicized before it is peer reviewed.
content: Researchers have responded to the challenge of the coronavirus with a commitment to speed and cooperation, featuring the rapid sharing of preliminary findings through “preprints,” scientific manuscripts that have not yet undergone formal peer review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Downsizing From a Two-Bedroom to a Studio
description: A couple moved from a two-bedroom to a studio late last fall. But even after four months of quarantine, they don’t regret the decision.
content: Cooped up at home these last four months, many New Yorkers have found themselves longing for larger apartments. But Kayla Oberlin and her partner Inbar Madar, who moved from a two-bedroom in Bushwick to a studio apartment in a Williamsburg high-rise late last fall, are not among them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geneva Abdul and Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta says passengers who don’t wear masks face a health screening.
description: Delta Air Lines said it would require passengers unable to wear face masks because of health conditions to undergo a medical clearance at the airport before boarding — or the passengers should “reconsider travel” altogether.
content: Delta Air Lines said it would require passengers unable to wear face masks because of health conditions to undergo a medical clearance at the airport before boarding — or the passengers should “reconsider travel” altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucie Langston
title: I Am Stuck Between Two Lives During This Pandemic
description: An artist battles anxiety by trying to stay present.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Kiana Hayeri
title: For Women in Afghan Security Forces, a Daily Battle
description: A new generation of women is moving to take up leadership roles in Afghanistan. The price is a daily barrage of abuse, and the fear that not much has changed.
content: KHOST, Afghanistan — Motivated, educated and fresh from finishing police academy in Turkey, Second Lt. Zala Zazai had stellar qualifications for the job she took in eastern Afghanistan in June. It all mattered little once she started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick
title: Three Coronavirus Vaccine Developers Report Promising Initial Results
description: Early trials showed a good immune response in vaccinated subjects, but one researcher sounded a note of caution: “There is still a long way to go.”
content: LONDON — The race for a vaccine against the coronavirus intensified on Monday as three competing laboratories released promising results from early trials in humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Prominent U.S. Figure Skating Coach Accused of Sex Abuse in Lawsuit
description: Accusations of sexual misconduct against Richard Callaghan, who coached Tara Lipinski to an Olympic gold medal in 1998, have been ongoing for two decades.
content: Legal pressure on Richard Callaghan, a disgraced elite American figure skating coach, ratcheted up Monday with the filing of a lawsuit accusing of him of years of sexual abuse and accusing the sport’s national governing body of not doing enough to stop it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: What Are Federal Agents Doing in Portland?
description: A militarized crackdown raises an outcry from local leaders: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Armed federal agents are patrolling the streets of Portland against the wishes of local leaders, and the president refuses to guarantee that he won’t contest the official results of the election. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nyimas Laula and Richard C. Paddock
title: With Tourists Gone, Bali Workers Return to Farms and Fishing
description: Many resort workers have gone home to villages and small towns, taking up traditional ways of earning a living to feed themselves and their families.
content: LALANGLINGGAH VILLAGE, Indonesia — Ni Nyoman Ayu Sutaryani, a mother of three, made a steady living for two decades working as a masseuse and yoga instructor at Bali’s luxury hotels and spas. Now at 37 she finds herself back on the farm of her childhood village here, standing precariously at the top of a tall bamboo ladder, picking cloves.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: In 5 Minutes, You Can Have a (Slightly) Tidier Bedroom
description: Books, jewelry, chargers, assorted junk ... let’s take a few minutes to make your nightstand a place of zen.
content: Books, jewelry, chargers, assorted junk ... let’s take a few minutes to make your nightstand a place of zen.

title: Trump Plans to Deploy More Law Enforcement Officers Amid Protests
